{{Infobox school | name = Academy of Our Lady of Perpetual Help | image = Perpetuo logo.png | imagesize = 250px | caption = | motto = ''Esto perpetua'' | motto_translation = Be everlasting | native_name = Academia del Perpetuo Socorro | established = 1921 | type = [[Private school|Private]], [[Coeducational]] | affiliations = [[Roman Catholic|Catholic]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Juan de Puerto Rico]] | streetaddress = 704 Marti Street | city = [[Miramar, Puerto Rico|Miramar, Santurce]] | country = [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]] | zipcode = 00907 | coordinates = {{Coord|18|27|16|N|66|5|5|W|type:edu_region:US-PR|display=inline,title}} | enrollment = 900 | enrollment_as_of = 2018-2019 | grades = [[Pre-prekindergarten|PPK]]-[[Twelfth grade|12]] | director = Padre Juan Santa | principal = Ms. Sarita Vázquez (PPK-K) Mrs. Jeannette Sánchez (1-6) Mrs. Enid Pereira (7-12) Mr. José Manuel Leavitt (Culture) | newspaper = ''Elipsis'', ''Zeitgeist'' | accreditation = [[Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools]]<ref name="MSA-Committee on Institution-Wide Accreditation">{{cite web|url=http://www.css-msa.org/search.php/ |title=MSA-Committee on Institution-Wide Accreditation |accessdate=2009-07-31 |author=MSA-CIWA |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wRXHJRCr?url=http://www.css-msa.org/search.php/ |archivedate=2011-02-12 }}</ref> | free_label = | free_text = | free_label1 = | free_text1 = | free_label2 = | free_text2 = | free_label3 = | free_text3 = | free_label4 = | free_text4 = | free_label5 = | free_text5 = | homepage = www.aps-pr.org }} '''Academia del Perpetuo Socorro''' (English: "Academy of Our Lady of Perpetual Help") was founded in 1921 as a Catholic parochial school of the Perpetuo Socorro Parish at the Archdiocese of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]. The school is located in [[Miramar, Puerto Rico|Miramar]] in [[Puerto Rico]]'s capital city of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. Students, teachers and alumni commonly refer to their school as Perpetuo. The school has historically been known to be a very prestigious school, traditionally educating young men and women who are to become influential leaders of Puerto Rican society. The school is featured prominently in Magali Garcia Ramis's novel ''Felices Dias Tio Sergio".
Many graduates attend top-ranked colleges and universities. Perpetuo provides academic instruction in Math, Sciences, History, English, Spanish, and Religion. It also provides a variety of athletic intercollegiate teams for its students as well as academic teams, specifically its Math, Model UN, Forensics, High School Choir, Drama Club and History teams. Perpetuo has 42 organized clubs, a varsity program in ten sports, four student publications and a yearbook, a Student Council, and an Honor Society for qualified students. It also offers membership for a Jr. Honor Society and an Honor Academy.
Students participate in a wide range of extracurricular activities ranging from Drama Club to community service. Every year, a handful of students have the opportunity to participate in a community service trip to [[Guatemala]], [[Peru]], and [[Honduras]]. Students spend two weeks with nuns in villages helping build houses, schools and also sharing time with local children as part of a community development program. Also, rising juniors have the opportunity to participate in a European Educational Trip coordinated by school officials.
==Mission== The goal of the Academia del Perpetuo Socorro is the complete development of the student - spiritually, mentally, morally, socially, culturally, and physically in order to live a full life and to prepare for his/her final goal - union with God. To this end, the school works to create a Catholic academic community in which faith, knowledge, and recreation are shared in a spirit of freedom, love, and creativity. The school, however, does not emphasize religion over other subjects, accepts students of all faiths and does not impose religious requirements such as baptism, confirmation or [[church attendance]] as a condition for continued attendance.
The school provides one of the most encompassing and through education experiences available to Puerto Rican students. It is known to be the stepping stone many future leaders of Puerto Rican society have prior to being educated in elite American institutions and becoming influential professionals.
==Motto== "Esto Perpetua" translated as "This Endures" stressing how the Catholic values and formal academic education learned at this school, symbolized in the school seal by the oil lamp over the open book, (as in burning the midnight oil) are to permeate individuals and society forever.
In short this motto is a reference to how the school's positive influence is eternal.
==Clubs== {{col-list|colwidth=18em| *Computer Club *Choir *Drama Club *United Nations *Honor Society *Jr. Honor Society *Honor Academy *Helping Hands *Law Club *Youth Ministry *Pro-life *Journalism *Psychology Club *Photography Club *Environmental Club *Math Club *English Forensics *Spanish Forensics *Zeitgeist Literary Magazine *Elipsis *Student Council *Girl Up *Positive Thinking Club *Meme Club *Sebastianism Youth Ministry
==Sports teams== Academia del Perpetuo Socorro has the largest gymnasium in the Caribbean. This gymnasium has three wooden volleyball courts that can also be transformed into two basketball courts. The gymnasium also has a small gym where athletes, faculty members, and students can go to do exercise.
Perpetuo has a varsity program in ten sports: {{col-list|colwidth=30em| *Golf *Basketball *Bowling *Baseball *Tennis *Volleyball *Softball *Soccer *Indoor soccer *Cross-country *Track and field *Swimming }}
==Notable alumni== {{col-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Benicio del Toro]], [[Academy Award]] and [[Golden Globe Award]] winning actor * [[Cristina Córdova]], sculptor * [[Gabriel Ríos]], musician * [[Henry Darrow]], stage and film actor * [[Lawrence La Fountain-Stokes]], scholar * [[Gustavo Gelpí]], U.S. district judge * [[Magali García Ramis]], writer * [[Marisol Calero]], actress and singer * [[Pedro Rosselló]], [[Governor of Puerto Rico|7th Governor of Puerto Rico]] * [[Xavier Romeu]], attorney and politician * [[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]], [[Apollo 11]] astronaut * Joaquin Bacardí, President and CEO, Bacardí Corporation * [[Roy Brown (Puerto Rican musician)|Roy Brown]], singer/songwriter * [[Ana María Polo]], lawyer/arbitrator * Andrés Viglucci, Pulitzer Prize winning journalist at the Miami Herald * Carlos A. Picón, Director [[Colnaghi]] Galeries, New York; 1990-2017, Curator in Charge of the Department of Greek and Roman Art at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City * [[Josie de Guzman]], actress and singer * [[Johanna Rosaly]], actress, singer, and television host }}
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.text:
{{copypaste|url=https://photos.state.gov/libraries/vietnam/8621/pdf-forms/VN-Grading-System.pdf|date=November 2016}} {{grading}} The [[Vietnam]]ese [[grading (education)|grading system]] is an academic [[grading (education)|grading system]] utilized in [[Vietnam]]. It is based on a 0-10 point scale, similar to the [[Academic grading in the United States|US 1.0-4.0 scale]].
Typically when an [[United States|American]] educational institution requests a grade-point average ([[GPA]]) calculated on the 4 point scale, the student will be expected to do a direct mathematical conversion, so 10 becomes 4.0, 7.5 becomes 3.0, etc. This makes sense from a practical standpoint. In reality, however, it is completely inaccurate.
In the Vietnamese system, a score of ten is rarely given. In contrast, a 4.0 in a U.S. classroom is not unusual, nor is someone with a 4.0 GPA overall. According to the Research Center for Vocational, Technical and Higher Education under the [[Ministry of Education and Training (Vietnam)|Vietnamese Ministry of Education]], someone with a 7.5 GPA will probably be in the top 10-15% of his or her class.
The practice of most Vietnamese colleges is not to provide [[Transcript (education)|official transcripts]] to other universities on behalf of their students. Students can request a signed and stamped original transcript from their school, and then have copies certified with a red stamp at a government office. Translation services are also available at such offices.
== Grade conversion table == Source: EducationUSA Vietnam, [[United States Ambassador to Vietnam|U.S. Embassy in Hanoi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://photos.state.gov/libraries/vietnam/8621/pdf-forms/VN-Grading-System.pdf|title=Basic Information About Vietnamese Grading System|publisher=EducationUSA Vietnam. [[U.S. Embassy in Hanoi]]|location=170 Ngoc Khanh Str., Ba Dinh Dist., Hanoi|accessdate=August 27, 2016}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- !Vietnam's Grading System!! colspan="2" |Equivalents !Vietnamese Description !English Description !% of students receiving this score |- | 9-10 ||A+||4.0 |Xuất sắc |Outstanding |Less than 5% of students |- | 8-9 ||A||3.5 |Giỏi |Excellent / Very Good |5-10% |- | 7-8 ||B+||3.0 |Khá |Good |About 20-25% |- | 6-7 ||B||2.5 |Trung Bình |Average |About 40-50% |- | 5-6 ||C||2.0 |Đạt |Pass |About 5-10% |- | <5 || D/F || =<1.0 | Không đạt/Trượt | Fail | For fail courses |- |}
In practice, most U.S. universities used a standardized acceptance of A, B, C, D's only. Thus any A+'s, B+, C+ will be down-convert to A, B, C respectively.
'''Standardized Table to Convert University GPAs'''
{| class="wikitable" |- !Vietnam's Grading System!! colspan="2" |Equivalents !Vietnamese Description !English Description |- | 8.0-10.0 ||A||4.0 |Xuất Sắc |Excellent / Outstanding |- |6.5-7.9 ||B||3.0 |Giỏi |Good |- | 5.0-6.4 ||C||2.0 |Trung Bình |Average |- | 4.0-4.9 ||D||1.0 |Không Đạt |Marginal |- |<4.0||F||0.0 |Trượt |Fail |}
==Credit hours==
Some universities in Vietnam notes standardized [[Course credit|credit hours]], which can translate directly over to the U.S. system. Some instead notes class hours of 15, 30, 45, 60 ... etc. which needs to be converted into credit hours by dividing class hours by 15. Thus a 15-hour class is equivalent to 1 credit hours, a 45-hour class is equivalent to 3 credit hours.
==Method of calculating GPAs==
Most universities convert GPAs class by class. Each class is evaluated for credit hours equivalent. Each class grade point is evaluated in its native grade point, then converted to A, B, C, D, F. Then convert the individual class grade to the 4.0 system. Next, multiply each class grade point by the number of credit hours for the respective class. Finally, total up the points, and divide by the total number credit hours to arrive at the final GPA.
The original article can be found at the [[Embassy of the United States, Saigon|U.S. Embassy's]] Education USA office located at: 1st Floor, Rose Garden Tower, 170 Ngoc Khanh St., Hanoi, Vietnam
https://photos.state.gov/libraries/vietnam/8621/pdf-forms/VN-Grading-System.pdf
==High school credit system==
[[Education in Vietnam#Middle school and secondary school education|High schools]] seem to use a slightly modified GPA system, with higher criteria to receive the equivalent grading letter scale. High school classes are standardized in most Vietnamese public schools, with the respective classes and Grade Point tables listed below.
{| class="wikitable" |+'''Vietnamese Standardized High School Classes''' |'''Vietnamese names''' |'''English names''' |- |Toán |Mathematics |- |Vật Lí |Physics |- |Hóa Học |Chemistry |- |Sinh Học |Biology |- |Tin Học |Informatics |- |Ngữ văn (Trước đây gọi là môn Văn - Tiếng Việt) |Literature |- |Lịch Sử |History |- |Địa Lí |Geography |- |Ngoại Ngữ Tiếng Anh |English |- |Công nghệ (Trước đây gọi là môn Kĩ thuật) |Technology |- |Giáo Dục Quốc Phòng |National Defense Education |- |Thể Dục |Physical Education / Gymnastics |- |Giáo Dục Công Dân |Civics |- |Điểm Trung Bình Các Môn Học (ĐTBCM) |Subjects’ average mark / GPA |}
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{One source|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox university | name = AIT - Academy of Information Technology | native_name = | native_name_lang = | other_name = | former_name = | image = AIT Sydney, Logo, Horizontal.png | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = | motto_lang = | mottoeng = | established = {{Start date|1999}} | closed = | type = | parent = | affiliation = | endowment = | budget = | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chancellor = | president = | vice-president = | superintendent = | provost = | vice_chancellor= | rector = | principal = | dean = Peter NSW | province = | country = [[Australia]] | coor = {{coord|-33.881942|151.195257|type:edu|display=inline,title}} | campus = Sydney, Melbourne | former_names = | language = | free_label = | free = | colors = | colours = | athletics = | sports = | nickname = AIT | mascot = | affiliations = |location = Level 2, 7 Kelly Street, [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]], [[New South Wales|NSW]], 2007, [[Australia]] | website = {{URL|http://www.ait.edu.au/}} | logo = | footnotes = }} '''AIT, Creative Technology Educators''' (also known as the ''Academy of Information Technology'') is a specialist higher education and vocational education institution based in [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]], [[Australia]],<ref name="Australian Government Study Assist">{{cite web|last=Australian Government|title=Study Assist|url=http://studyassist.gov.au/sites/studyassist/mytertiarystudyoptions/providers-that-offer-commonwealth-assistance/pages/heproviderprofile?title=Academy%20of%20Information%20Technology|publisher=Australian Government|accessdate=20 April 2012}}</ref> with a second campus opening in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] in 2015.<ref name="Welcome to Our Campus">{{cite web|last=AIT|title=Welcome to Our Campus|url=http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/about-us/campus/|publisher=AIT|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref> AIT was established in 1999, and specialises in three disciplines: [[digital media]], [[information technology]], and business.<ref>{{cite web|title=CRICOS, Dept. of Education, Australia|url=http://cricos.deewr.gov.au/Institution/InstitutionDetails.aspx?ProviderID=2155|accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref> AIT is a member of the [http://www.redhilleducation.com/ RedHill Education] group, alongside [[Greenwich English College]], [[Go Study Australia]], and the [[International School of Colour and Design]] (ISCD).<ref name="RedHill Education: Our Businesses">{{cite web|last=RedHill Education|title=Our Businesses|url=http://www.redhilleducation.com/our-businesses.html|publisher=RedHill Education|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref> AIT was the first in Australia to offer courses in [[Motion capture]] technology, and has the latest markerless Motion Capture system installed in its Sydney campus,<ref name="AIT Course Guide">{{cite book|last=Edward|first=Keller|title=AIT Course Guide / Pamphlet|year=2012|publisher=Academy of Information Technology|location=Sydney, Australia|pages=5}}</ref> in 2013, AIT was still the first Mobile Applications Development course provided. AIT holds and participates in many events, including the AIT Oscar Night, the AIT Games Night, and the Vivid Light Festival.
AIT is recognised as a quality tertiary education provider by the Australian Government’s Tertiary Education Quality & Standards Agency (TEQSA) and the Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA).
==Courses== '''2D & 3D Animation''' <ref name="2015/16 AIT Course Guide">{{cite book|last=AIT|title=2015/16 AIT Course Guide / Booklet|year=2015|publisher=AIT|location=Sydney, Australia|pages=14–37}}</ref> *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150914024147/http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/animation-courses/3d-animation-courses/ Bachelor of Interactive Media (Specialisation: Animation)] *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/animation-courses/study-animation-sydney/ Diploma of Digital Media Technologies (Specialisation: Animation)]
'''Design'''<ref name="2015/16 AIT Course Guide"/> *Bachelor of Interactive Media (Specialisation: Design) *Diploma of Digital Media Technologies (Specialisation: Design)
'''Film Making''' <ref name="2015/16 AIT Course Guide"/> *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/film-making-courses/study-film-making/ Bachelor of Interactive Media (Specialisation: Film Making)] *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/film-making-courses/how-to-make-a-film/ Diploma of Digital Media Technologies (Specialisation: Film Making)]
'''Game Design''' <ref name="2015/16 AIT Course Guide"/> *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/game-design-courses/game-development-courses/ Bachelor of Interactive Media (Specialisation: Game Development)] *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/game-design-courses/game-design-courses-sydney/ Diploma of Digital Media Technologies (Specialisation: Game Development)]
'''Digital Design''' <ref name="2015/16 AIT Course Guide"/> *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/digital-design-courses/bachelor-of-digital-design/ Bachelor of Digital Design] *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/digital-design-courses/diploma-of-design/ Diploma of Design]
'''IT''' <ref name="2015/16 AIT Course Guide"/> *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/it-courses/bachelor-of-it/ Bachelor of IT (Mobile Applications Development)] *[http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/courses/it-courses/diploma-of-software-development/ Diploma of Software Development]
==Facilities==
===Motion Capture=== The [http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/motion-capture-facility/ Motion Capture] (or Organic Motion) is a markerless motion capture system that was designed and manufactured by [http://www.organicmotion.com/ Organic Motion] of New York. This type of technology was the first of its kind implemented in Australia.<ref name="AIT Course Guide"/> The Motion Capture, aka MoCap, allows users to motion track and animate their 3D characters easily.<ref name="Motion Capture">{{cite web|last=AIT|title=Motion Capture|url=http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/motion-capture-facility/|publisher=AIT|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref>
===Green Screen Room=== The [http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/green-screen-room/ Green Screen Room] is a state of the art filming environment located on the Sydney campus. The space was launched on 28 May 2014 and allows students to extend their editing skills in [[Adobe Premiere]] and [[Adobe After Effects]] for [[Green Screen]] compositing.<ref name="Green Screen Room">{{cite web|last=AIT|title=Green Screen Room|url=http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/green-screen-room/|publisher=AIT|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref>
==Student Council & Social Activities==
===Student Representative Council=== [[File:AIT SRC Logo.png|thumb|right|The AIT Student Representative Council (SRC) logo]] The Student Representative Council (SRC) is a small group of students selected by the student body. Their job is to help improve the quality of life on the AIT campus, and do so by communicating with teachers and staff members on the student bodies behalf. The current president of the SRC is Mikhaila Katte.<ref name="Student Life at AIT">{{cite web|last=AIT|title=Student Life at AIT|url=http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/about-us/life-ait/|publisher=AIT|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref>
===Clubs=== As of 2015 AIT currently has five clubs running: the 3D Club, Film Club, Drawing Club, Table Top Club and Fight Club.<ref name="Student Life at AIT"/> These clubs are overseen and assisted by the SRC.
===Events=== AIT holds regular events throughout the year, held by a mixture of staff members, teachers and the SRC. Smaller events include barbecues, Christmas parties and Trivia Nights.
====AIT Oscar Night==== The [http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/ait-oscar-night/ AIT Oscar Night] is an annual event held at AIT. This event allows student works to be recognised and rewarded by their teacher and peers in the fields of Animation and Film. The event is run by Film Coordinator, [http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/about-us/meet-the-team/patrick-huang/ Patrick Huang].<ref name="AIT Oscar Night">{{cite web|last=AIT|title=AIT Oscar Night|url=http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/ait-oscar-night/|publisher=AIT|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref>
====AIT Games Night==== The [http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/ait-game-night/ AIT Games Night] is an annual event held at AIT. This event features student games alongside other activities like [[cosplay]] competitions. Prizes are awarded to the best student games. This event is run by both the teachers and SRC, allowing multiple activities to run in one night.<ref name="AIT Games Night">{{cite web|last=AIT|title=AIT Games Night|url=http://www.ait.nsw.edu.au/ait-game-night/|publisher=AIT|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref>
====Vivid==== In 2015 AIT participated in the [[Vivid Sydney|Vivid Light Festival]]. Their entry, titled "Lightwell", was a collaborative task between teachers and students. The structure itself was created by Helen Goritsas, Patrick Huang, Nik Sutila, Adam Katz, Sharon Sanders, Carlton Zhu, Kwan Chemsripong and Kriss Mahatumaratana. The interactive structure displayed a collection of student artworks onto a wall along Walsh Bay, Sydney.<ref name="Lightwell">{{cite web|last=Vivid Sydney|title=Lightwell|url=http://www.vividsydney.com/event/light/lightwell|publisher=Vivid Sydney|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of universities in Australia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs |type = LEPL |logo = File:Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Georgia logo.jpg |logo_width = 175 |logo_caption = Logo of Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Georgia |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = 1930's |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |jurisdiction = [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] |headquarters = Gmiri Kursantebi Str. #4. 0178
[[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (Country)|Georgia]] |employees = |chief1_name = [[Giorgi Gakharia]] |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |website = {{url|www.policeacademy.ge}} }} The '''Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Georgia''' ({{lang-ka|საქართველოს შინაგან საქმეთა სამინისტროს აკადემია}}, ''sak'art'velos shinagan sak'met'a akademia''), also known as the '''Police Academy of Georgia''' (საქართველოს პოლიციის აკადემია, ''sak'art'velos polits'iis akademia''), the Legal Entity of Public Law of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Georgia, the mission of which is to integrate the knowledge in the sphere of law, including the knowledge in the field of police regulation, its updating with the standards oriented on public service and training the personnel of higher values and principles with practical skills and knowledge as well as the skills necessary for lawyers with the use of innovative methods for public and private sectors. ==History== The Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs was founded in 1930 and has been changed many times since the day of its foundation. In 1930 the structure of the school of senior staff of the Militia changed and launched the program for training of ordinary police officers on its basis. From January, 1941 the School of Senior Staff of Militia was awarded the name of the Tbilisi School of Militia of the Commissariat of Internal Affairs of the USSR. In the documents dating back to 1941 we first meet women staff among the students and listeners. By the decision of the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Georgia in 1994 the High School of the Militia was transformed into the Academy of MIA. On March 15, 2006, the Special Training Center was incorporated into the Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. On June 1, 2012 the Archive of the Ministry of Internal Affairs was transferred to the Academy. The Archive of the Ministry of Internal Affairs unites the archives of the former State Security Committee, the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the Central Committee of Communist Party of the Georgian SSR. Under the initiative of the Minister of Internal Affairs, in 2016, the Academy introduced to the remote education, which covers all regions of Georgia. It was founded the Alumni Association, joining the first 39 MA graduates of 2016.[http://policeacademy.gov.ge/ka/about-the-academy/history History] ==Mission of the Academy== The academy is committed to becoming a dignified member of the European family of police education and to overcome the existing challenges on the basis of study, research and analysis of Western achievements in the sphere of police regulation.[http://policeacademy.gov.ge/ka/about-the-academy/about-us About Us - Police Academy] ==Activities== Preparation of specialists with higher education for the system of the Ministry; training of specialists with special professional education for the Ministry and other military institutions, training and retraining of the personnel for special institutions of the executive government, as well as police system and state security service and raising the qualification of the staff; preparation of specialists with higher education for public and private sector; organization and/or testing relevant training courses for preparing specialists on the basis of a contract; archival activities, establishment and development of international contacts in the field of archive and case management, participation in the activities of profile international organizations within the scope of its competence; educational and scientific-research activities; publishing activities; realization of products created during the educational and scientific-research activities; production and realization of production (invention and utility model) created during the scientific-research and laboratory activities; entrepreneurial business activities in the case provided for by the Statute; other activities envisaged by the law, resolution of the Government of Georgia and/or the Statute, unless otherwise provided by the relevant legislation. ==Contact details:== Gmiri Kursantebi str. #4, 0178 [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] Tel.: * Info Service — (032) 241 40 41 * Duty Service — (032) 241 37 06 * Info Service — (032) 241 36 90 * Duty Service — (032) 241 37 08[http://112.gov.ge/?m=4 Contacts - 112.gov.ge] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Police academies]] [[Category:Education in Tbilisi]]

revision.text:
'''Andreas Constantine Papadakis''' FLS (17 June 1938 – 10 June 2008) was a Cypriot-born British academic, entrepreneur and leading figure in the field of [[Publishing|architectural publishing]]. He opened the Academy Bookshop in [[Holland Street, Kensington|Holland Street]], Kensington in 1964 and moved into publishing as Academy Editions in 1968. From then until 1990, when he sold the company to VCH Germany (now part of [[John Wiley & Sons|John Wiley]]) he published more than a thousand titles mainly on art, architecture and the decorative arts.<ref name="times">Anon. (2008) Andreas Papadakis: Publisher; Times Online Obituary. ''Times Online'', 30 Jul. [internet] Available at: http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article4424818.ece <!--accessed 30 April 2009--></ref> He was the first to publish (in USA - [[RCS MediaGroup|Rizzoli]] 'and latter [[St. Martin's Press]]) many international architects in the 'Architectural Monographs No...' series,<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/gp/search/ref=sr_adv_b/?search-alias=stripbooks&unfiltered=1&field-keywords=&field-author=&field-title=Architectural+Monographs+No&field-isbn=&field-publisher=&node=&url=&field-feature_browse-bin=&field-binding_browse-bin=&field-subject=&field-language=&field-dateop=&field-datemod=&field-dateyear=&sort=price&Adv-Srch-Books-Submit.x=26&Adv-Srch-Books-Submit.y=16 Architectural Monographs No...]</ref> which included [[Alvar Aalto]] (No 4), [[Michael Graves]] (No 5), [[Edwin Lutyens]] (No 6), [[John Soane]] (No 8), [[Terry Farrell (architect)|Terry Farrell]] (No 9), [[Richard Rogers]] (No 10), [[Mies van der Rohe]] (No 11), [[Hassan Fathy]] (No 13), [[Tadao Ando]] (No 14), [[Daniel Libeskind]] (No 16), etc.; and Victor Arwas’s ''Art Deco'', first published in 1980 remains the standard work on the subject.<ref name="telegraph">Anon. (2008) Andreas Papadakis, ''Telegraph.co.uk'', 18 Aug. [internet] Available at: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/2581290/Andreas-Papadakis.html <!--accessed 30 April 2009--></ref>
==Early life== Papadakis was born in [[Nicosia]], [[Cyprus]] on 17 June 1938 and relocated to London in 1956. He obtained a DIC from [[Imperial College London|Imperial College]] and a PhD from [[Brunel University]]. In 1964 he bought a house in Holland Street, [[Kensington]] without realising that the shop (then a dry cleaners) on the ground floor could not be used for residential purposes.<ref name="times"/> He decided to open a bookshop. The Academy Bookshop began as a general bookshop. His first publications were finely bound limited editions of other publishers’ books but he soon decided that he would prefer to make his own and began in 1967 with a large format paperback of [[Aubrey Beardsley]]’s prints, an ideal title to attract the customers of [[Biba]], who had recently opened her shop just round the corner in Kensington Church Street. The Beardsley book was still in print when Academy was sold in 1990.<ref name="times"/><ref name="telegraph"/>
==Academy Editions & ''Architectural Design''== In 1971 Papadakis expanded his fast-growing business with the acquisition of the Tiranti publishing company and the London Art Bookshop. He moved the shop to No. 8 Holland Street, just opposite the Academy Bookshop and set about expanding the combined Academy/Tiranti list. Early publications included Jim Burns’s ''Arthropods'', Roger Bilcliffe’s ''Charles Rennie Mackintosh'', [[Bernard Rudofsky|Rudofsky]]’s [[Architecture Without Architects|''Architecture without Architects'']], [[Reyner Banham]]’s ''Design by Choice'', ''Alphonse Mucha, Complete Graphic Works'', and [[Rudolf Wittkower|Wittkower]]’s ''Architectural Principles in the Age of Humanism''.
In 1975 Papadakis bought the financially troubled ''Architectural Design'' magazine. This created some controversy because of his non-architectural background and his unwillingness to give his unconditional support to one particular architectural style.<ref name="times"/><ref name="bd">Latham, I. (1988) Anniversaries: Edited Highlights. ''Building Design'', 30 Sep. p. 28</ref><ref name="suntimes">Pearman, H. (1993) Function Follows Farm. ''The Sunday Times'', 25 Jul. p. 21</ref> The controversy increased with the publication of [[Charles Jencks]]’s ''The Language of Post-Modern Architecture'' in 1977, which was in its sixth edition by the time he sold Academy in 1990.
Both ''Architectural Design'' and Academy Editions continued to publish [[Postmodern architecture|Post-Modern]], [[Classical architecture|Classical]] and [[Deconstructivism|Deconstructivist]] projects throughout the 1980s while Papadakis himself actively fostered the pluralist debate through seminars, conferences and exhibitions at the [[University of Westminster|Polytechnic of Central London]], the [[Architectural Association]], the [[Royal Institute of British Architects|RIBA]], the [[German Architecture Museum]] in [[Frankfurt]], and through his Academy Forums at the [[Tate|Tate Gallery]] and the [[Royal Academy|Royal Academy of Arts]], where he also founded the annual Architecture Lecture.<ref name="times"/><ref name="bd"/>
In 1990, Papadakis sold what was by now the Academy Group Ltd. with ''Architectural Design'' and the journals he had founded: ''Architectural Monographs'', ''Art and Design'' and the ''Journal of Philosophy and the Visual Arts''. He left the group at the end of 1992 and was banned by a non-competition clause from publishing for five years.<ref name="bdd">Anon. (1993) Rise and Fall of PoMo King. ''Building Design'', 15 Jan.</ref>
==Papadakis Publisher and Restoration Projects== In 1997, Papadakis founded a new publishing house, Papadakis Publisher, with his daughter Alexandra. In addition to books on architecture and the decorative arts the company broadened its scope to include books on natural science, including the acclaimed<ref name="seedscience">Thompson, K. (2007) Book Review: Seeds, Time Capsules of Life. ''Seed Science Research'' 17, p. 71 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press)</ref><ref name="time">Anon. (2008) Fruit: Edible, Inedible, Incredible. ''Time Magazine Online'', [internet] Available at: http://www.time.com/time/photogallery/0,29307,1846523_1775210,00.html <!--accessed 30 April 2009--></ref><ref name="about">Richins, V. (2008) Fruit: Edible, Inedible, Incredible. ''About.com'', [internet] Available at: http://treesandshrubs.about.com/od/bookproductreviews/gr/FruitBookReview.htm<!--accessed 30 April 2009--></ref> series ''Pollen'', ''Seeds'' and ''Fruit'' in association with the [[Kew Gardens|Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]], leading to his election as a [[Linnean Society of London|Fellow of the Linnean Society]].<ref name="linnean">Linnean Society of London, The (2006) ''Annual Report 2006'' p. 31 [internet] Available at: http://www.linnean.org/fileadmin/images/Publications/Annual_Report_2006_Complete_web.pdf<!--accessed 30 April 2009--></ref> ''Pollen'' and ''Seeds'' were awarded a joint gold medal by the American Independent Publishers’ Association in 2006 as Outstanding Books of the Year, and his first science book ''Why the Lion Grew its Mane'' was long-listed by the [[Royal Society]] in 2007.<ref name="times" />
[[File:Church Island House in the Thames, Staines.jpg|thumb|Church Island House in the Thames]]
As Papadakis’s business ventures were increasingly successful, he purchased several properties for restoration, including the medieval Kilbees Farm in [[Winkfield|Winkfield, Berkshire]] and Dauntsey Park House in [[Wiltshire]], although the latter project ended in 2005 when planning permission was refused.<ref name="suntimes"/><ref name="telegraphdp">Aslet, C. (2005) Planner in the Works. ''Telegraph.co.uk'', 27 Jan [internet]. Available at: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/3338840/Planner-in-the-works.html<!--accessed 30 April 2009--></ref> In 1987 Papadakis bought Church Island in the Thames and commissioned Dr. [[Basil Al Bayati]], an architect whose books 'Architect'<ref name=architect> {{Cite book | last = Al Bayati | first = Basil | title = Architect | publisher = Academy Editions/St. Martin's Press | year = 1988 | location = London | isbn = 0-85670-925-5}} </ref> and 'Recent Works'<ref name=recentworks> {{Cite book | last = Al Bayati | first = Basil | title = Recent Works | publisher = Academy Editions/Ernst & Sohn | year = 1993 | location = London | isbn = 1-85490-170-2}} </ref> he had published, to design a house for him. “For his luxury mansion on his Greek-island-in-the-Thames, the great man chose not Michael Graves, one of the deconstructivists or even CZWG, but pragmatic classicist Basil Al Bayati, whom he instructed to design a country house in the English turn-of-the-century manner.”<ref name="secondcoming"> {{cite news | publisher = Building Design magazine | title = The Second Coming of Lutyens' Style | date = 16 September 1988 | edition = Vol. 7, no 6 | page = 11 }}</ref> The plan of the house is based on multiple units of structural geometrical forms and utilises extensive brickwork in a postmodern, art & craft style. It was “designed in a vernacular manner, using building materials similar to those traditionally used in the area.” <ref name=architect218> {{Cite book | last = Al Bayati | first = Basil | title = Architect | publisher = Academy Editions/St. Martin's Press | year = 1988 | page = 218 | location = London | isbn = 0-85670-925-5}} </ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Church Island House.jpg|thumb|right|Church Island House by Dr. Basil Al Bayati]] -->
In 1988, Church Island House was exhibited at the [[German Architecture Museum]] in [[Frankfurt]] in an exhibition titled The Architecture of Pluralism that included work by [[James Gowan]], [[Terry Farrell (architect)|Terry Farrell]], [[Charles Jencks]] and some twenty other internationally recognised architects.
In 2007 he purchased [[Monkey Island, Bray|Monkey Island Hotel]] in [[Bray, Berkshire]] but died a few months afterwards.<ref name="times" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.papadakis.net Papadakis Publisher]

{{unreferenced|date=January 2012}} The '''Aufbaugymnasium''' ("Structured Grammar School") is a school for mature students in Germany and Austria. It serves students who graduated from a [[Hauptschule]] or [[Realschule]] and are headed for the [[Abitur]]. It is not to be confused with a traditional [[Gymnasium (Germany)|Gymnasium]], which serves young students who have not graduated from another [[secondary school]] before.
[[Category:Education in Germany]] [[Category:Education in Austria]] [[Category:Gymnasium (school) system]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Basis Educational Group | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | trading_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{Lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | romanized_name = | former_name = | type = | traded_as = | ISIN = | ISIN2 = | industry = for-profit education | genre = | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = <!-- if known: {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[state]], [[country]] --> | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location = [[Tucson, Arizona]] | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | num_locations = | num_locations_year = <!-- Year of num_locations data (if known) --> | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | brands = | production = | production_year = <!-- Year of production data (if known) --> | services = | revenue = | revenue_year = <!-- Year of revenue data (if known) --> | operating_income = | income_year = <!-- Year of operating_income data (if known) --> | net_income = <!-- or: | profit = --> | net_income_year = <!-- or: | profit_year = --><!-- Year of net_income/profit data (if known) --> | aum = <!-- Only for financial-service companies --> | assets = | assets_year = <!-- Year of assets data (if known) --> | equity = | equity_year = <!-- Year of equity data (if known) --> | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | members = | members_year = <!-- Year of members data (if known) --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | module = <!-- Used to embed other templates --> | website = {{URL|http://www.basised.com/}} | footnotes = | intl = <!-- Set positively ("true"/"yes"/etc) if company is international, otherwise omit --> }} '''Basis Educational Group''', styled '''BASIS.ed''', is a for-profit [[education management organization]] based in [[Tucson, Arizona]]. It serves primarily [[Basis Schools]], a non-profit [[charter management organization]] with offices in the same complex.
Basis comprises various companies organized by the regions in which the schools operate: Basis Schools, Inc., BTX Schools, Inc., Basis Washington D.C. ([[Washington D.C.]]), and Basis Baton Rouge ([[Louisiana]]). In 2018, the company claims twenty-five schools and 17,000 students, which matches publicly available enrollment numbers from Basis Schools. In 2015, Basis Schools had enrolled 12,0140 students.<ref name="jw2017">{{cite web|last1=Woodworth|first1=James L|title=Charter Management Organizations 2017|url=https://credo.stanford.edu/pdfs/CMO%20FINAL.pdf| publisher=Center for Research on Education Outcomes|accessdate=23 January 2018|date=2017}}</ref>{{rp|84}}
== Basis Independent School locations == Basis Independent Schools are private, tuition-based schools using the Basis curriculum.
=== New York === *Basis Independent Brooklyn *Basis Independent Manhattan
=== California === *Basis Independent Silicon Valley *Basis Independent Fremont
=== Virginia === *Basis Independent McLean
== Basis International School locations ==
=== China === *Basis International School Shenzhen (BISZ) （Shenzhen, China) *Basis International School Guangzhou (BIGZ)（Guangzhou, China） *Basis International School Park Lane Harbour (BIPH)（Huizhou,China） *Basis International school Hangzhou (BIHZ) (Hangzhou, China)
===Thailand=== *Basis International School Bangkok (opening scheduled September 2019)<ref name="tn180128">{{cite web|title=BASIS brings its international school to Bangkok |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/lifestyle/30337329| publisher=The Nation |accessdate=20 November 2018|date=January 2017}}</ref>
==Controversy== Critics observe that the relation between Basis Educational Group and Basis Schools is not arms-length. As a result, there is little financial transparency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/opinions/articles/20121119editorial1121-charters-transparent.html |title=Charter transparency |publisher=Azcentral.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-17}}</ref> An investigative article in 2010 compared the founders' salary compared to the teachers and other public school administrators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://azstarnet.com/news/blogs/senor-reporter/sr-reporter-basis-school-execs-salaries-rose-fast/article_a428653c-d706-11df-9137-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Basis School Execs Salaries Rose Fast|publisher=Azcentral.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-20}}</ref>
The schools have suffered high attrition rates (senior classes are typically a third to a quarter of the size of the fifth grade class). Critics argue that Basis achieves good test scores in part by weeding out underperforming students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blogforarizona.com/blog/2013/04/conservatives-on-basis-charter-print-the-legend.html |title=conservatives on BASIS print the legend |publisher=blogforarizona.com |date= |accessdate=2013-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130501003341/http://www.blogforarizona.com/blog/2013/04/conservatives-on-basis-charter-print-the-legend.html |archivedate=2013-05-01 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tucsonweekly.com/TheRange/archives/2014/04/23/basis-and-university-high-are-top-us-high-schools-which-means|title= BASIS and University High are Top U.S. High Schools, which means...?|publisher=tucsonweekly.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogforarizona.net/basis-charters-education-model-success-by-attrition|title=Success by Attrition|publisher=blogforarizona.com|date= |accessdate=2014-06-22}}</ref>
In 2013, a request to expand was rejected by the [[District of Columbia Public Charter School Board]], which cited concerns about the high number of students who had withdrawn from the school since it opened.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/dc-charter-board-rejects-request-from-basis-to-expand/2013/04/16/32a735ee-a69a-11e2-8302-3c7e0ea97057_story.html|title=DC charter board rejects request from Basis to expand|publisher=washingtonpost.com|date= |accessdate=2014-06-24}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{redirect|CISV}} {{Infobox organization | logo = File:Alt CISV logo.tif | logo_size = 220px | type = [[Non-governmental organization]] |slogan=Building Global Friendship| name = CISV International | founded_date = 1950
[[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]], United States
[[Doris Twitchell Allen]] | location = [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], [[England]] (International Office)CISV Passport, 2009, Infofile T-03 | focus = [[peace education|Peace Education]] | homepage = {{url|http://www.cisv.org}} }} '''CISV International''' (''Formerly'' '''''Children's International Summer Villages''''') was founded in 1951http://www.cisv.org/about-us/about-cisv-int/founder/ by [[Doris Twitchell Allen]] and aims to educate and inspire action for a more just and peaceful world. The organisation operates international educational programmes on an annual basis to bring together participants from member countries. CISV also operates in smaller communities through its around 200 local Chapters in 69 countries.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cisv.org/mycisv/national-chapter-officials-directory/about-us/our-world/|title="Our World"|last=|first=|date=1 March 2017|website=CISV International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} CISV International is a [[UNESCO]] partner Non Governmental Organization (NGO), holds participatory status with the [[Council of Europe]] and is a candidate member of the [[European Youth Forum]].http://www.cisv.org/about-us/our-partners/ ==History== CISV was founded in 1951, after [[World War II]], by [[Doris Twitchell Allen]]. Since then, the organisation has expanded into around 69 countries, and over 150,000 delegates have participated in more than four thousand international CISV activities that delegates have made up over the course of these years.http://www.cisv.org/about-us/publications/ For Dr. Allen and the CISV organisation, children and youth were seen as the ideal starting point for peace education. Programmes were developed which offered young people opportunities to meet their peers from other countries and to form intercultural friendships and to learn about what life is really like where they come from. Local programmes give people the chance to learn about the cultures in their own communities and explore important themes related to peace and understanding. The first village was held in 1951 in Glendale, Ohio; commissioned for its 50th anniversary, the sculpture "How Alike I Am to You” was created in 2000 by Tim Werrell and stands on the property of the Harry Whiting Brown Community Center in Glendale, Ohio. ==CISV programmes== The CISV International delivers its education through its seven official programmes: * Village: Today, delegations composed of four children and one adult "Leader" from 10–12 countries come together for a four-week programme for 11-year-old children, who participate in activities based around simple activities that indirectly promote peace and understanding of each other. Each delegation consists of two boys, two girls, and an adult leader. Additionally, there are five or six Junior Counsellors (JCs, age 16–17) invited, who should be a care-taking "older sibling" for the 11-year-old. There is also a STAFF that takes cares of the camp and it is, usually, a group of 5-6 adults. The staff is responsible for organizing all the structure so the camp can happen. * Step Up: A three-week programme for participants 14–15 years of age. Delegations include 4 participants and an adult leader. In Step Up's participants can think of new rules for the camp, these will be discussed and voted upon in a so-called 'camp meeting'. Also, the delegates are largely responsible for putting together activities to promote social and leadership skills. Each delegation consists of two boys, two girls, and an adult leader. * Interchange: Involving only two countries, this programme spans up to two years. A delegation of 6–12 youth, aged 12–14, is selected from each participating country. In the programme one delegation will travel to visit for two or four weeks with the other's family. After those weeks and a little time in between, the delegations reciprocate. Each delegation has one adult leader, and may also have a Junior Leader. * Youth Meeting: An 8 or 15 day programme for either 12–13, 14–15, 16–18 or 19+. This programme is based on a specific theme. For youth 12–15 each delegation consists of six young people, and an adult leader. People at the age 16+ travel alone. * Seminar Camp: A three-week programme for youth 17–18 in which there is one or more (but not more than four) delegates from each participating country. Seminar Camps have a more direct educational approach, and youth are encouraged to form opinions on various world issues. Usually youth-directed, this program has only thirty participants in total. * International People's Project: CISV's newest international programme is open to people aged 19+ and is three weeks long. Participants participate in hands-on work contributing to a community project. * Mosaic: Mosaic is a programme that consists of projects with educational content, developed by local CISV Chapters worldwide. These projects empower individuals to be agents of change, reach out, and involve as many people as possible. The CISV International website provides more detailed information.http://www.cisv.org/cisv-programmes/ CISV Chapters also hold activities that aim to share the CISV experience within their local community. In addition to this CISV International delivers its education through: * '''Junior Branch (JB)''': Junior Branch is an integral, but self-governing youth-based part of the structure of CISV. Junior Branch develops intercultural skills and attitude through educational and administrative activities consistent with CISV Goals. * '''Mini Camp''': A weekend long camp within the local chapter. It is planned and run by local Juniors and leaders, often the older members of the chapter. It is a chance for participants to have a camp like experience locally and allows potential delegates and JCs to have a taste what a few days at camp may be like. Often delegate, leader and JC selection takes place at Mini Camps and activities can range from sports, to simulation activities to guest speakers and much more. * CISV also has other things you can do, such as being a leader, more commonly meant for the Village, Step-Up, and Interchange (Also for NYM). They are the ones who take the delegations to the Camp/Village. There are also usually 6 Junior Counselors (JC's) on a Village picked from chapters around the world who provide a link between children and adults on Villages. They are age 16-17 and it is common for there to be 2 JCs from the country the camp is being held in. On every programme there is a Staff team, usually from the hosting country although there are sometimes international staff. They are incharge of all the doings of the camp with the help of the JC's and the Leaders. When a camp is being run there is always a need for Host Families. These are families who have participants to stay at their houses when the camp has either not begun yet, has ended and participants have some time to wait before their flights leave or, in the case of a Village, when the leaders weekend off is underway. Another thing which is important is Junior Branch. There are many roles to be taken on throughout your local and national Junior Branch, these vary from country to country and national junior branch roles are usually taken on by Juniors aged 16+, however, you can contribute in many ways; from helping to plan your Junior Branch meetings to helping to raise money to host programmes. * == CISV International, National Associations and Chapters == The International Office of CISV is located in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], [[England]]. The Secretary General of the organisation is based there, along with a small team of officers and administrative staff. CISV International is an umbrella organisation, with over 70 members or National Associations (NAs). Each NA oversees and supports its local branches or Chapters. == Awards and prizes == * [[European Citizens' Prize]] 2013 ==Gallery== File:CISV_FlagFR_1995.jpg|CISV Flag File:Cisv_Song.jpg|CISV Song File:CISV_Members.jpg|70 countries File:CISV Board of Trustees in session AIM 2010.jpg|Board of Trustees in session AIM 2010 File:CISV_Graz.jpg|CISV Austria 1958 File:CISV_Graz_1958.jpg|CISV Austria 1958 File:CISV JB Example.jpg|Junior Branch == References == {{reflist}} * [http://www.cisv.org/about-us/about-cisv-int/ About CISV International] == External links == {{Commons category|CISV International}} * [http://www.cisv.org CISV International Website] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Children's charities based in England]] [[Category:Organizations with participatory status with the Council of Europe]] [[Category:Peace education]] [[Category:Summer camps]] [[Category:International educational organizations]] [[Category:Organisations based in Tyne and Wear]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1950]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2013}}
The '''Conference on Information Technology, Organisations and Teams''' ('''CITOT''') was held in 2007 and 2009.
In this conference, Information Technology and its application in organizations and teams is discussed. Subjects like evolution of Web technologies, small display devices as well as mobile and groupware systems are also subject of analysis and discussion.
CITOT 2007 conference received 35 papers. From those papers 10 were accepted as full and small papers, 3 were accepted as posters and 4 as workshop papers (2 workshops). The conference also has a workshop with a tutorial presentation about web Services and PHP (Bruno Pedro) and one invited speaker (Paulo Trezentos, Caixa Magica).
In 2007, the program committee included members from Europe, America, Australia and Africa: Anders Morch, University of Oslo (Norway), Carina Ihlstrom Eriksson, [[University College of Halmstad]] (Sweden), Carlos J. Costa, [[ISCTE]](Portugal), Clay Spinuzzi, [[University of Texas at Austin]] (USA), Gitesh K. Raikundalia, [[Victoria University, Australia]], Hanne Westh Nicolajsen, [[Technical University of Denmark]] (Denmark), Jose Leopoldo Nhampossa, [[Eduardo Mondlane University]] (Mozambique), Kalogiannakis Michail, University Paris 5 (France) and Petter Nielsen, Telenor (Norway)
In 2007, the reviewers were: António Maia, Universidade Aberta, Lisboa (Portugal), Manuela Aparício, ATML, Lisboa (Portugal), Mario Tavares, [[ISCTE]], Lisboa (Portugal), Silvia Jorge, [[Loures]] Municipality, Lisboa (Portugal) and Stephen Burgess, Victoria University (Australia)
In 2007, Organization Committee was composed of: Manuela Aparício, ATML, Lisboa (Portugal), Pedro Costa, [[IADE]] (Instituto de Artes Visuais, Design e Marketing), Lisboa (Portugal), Rita Coruche, Lusocredito (Portugal) and Maria Filomena Pereira, Lusocredito (Portugal).
CITOT 2007 was sponsored by LaSDI - Laboratory of Simulation and Dynamic Interaction, from [[ADETTI]]. CITOT 2009 was sponsored by ERP/ITML project.
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726200209/http://design.itml.org/citot2007/ CITOT2007] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726195517/http://events.itml.org/citot2009/ CITOT2009]
[[Category:Academic conferences]] [[Category:Information systems conferences]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Dan Peña | image = Dan at Guthrie Castle (Graduation Night).jpg | birth_name = Daniel Steven Peña Sr. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|8|10}} | birth_place = [[Jacksonville, Florida]], [[United States|USA]] | residence = [[Scotland]], [[United Kingdom]] | nationality = American | education = [[California State University, Northridge]] {{small|(BS)}} | occupation = Business Coach | salary = | networth = | title = | spouse = Sally Hall Peña | children = Daniel Steven Peña Jr., Derrick Peña and Kelly Peña | website = [http://www.danpena.co.uk danpena.co.uk] }}
'''Daniel Steven Peña Sr.'''<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/_DlggeBNaJSGMvRdTPvXVNoC740/appointments |title=Daniel Steven Pena - Personal Appointments (free information from Companies House) |website=beta.companieshouse.gov.uk |language=en|access-date=2017-04-12}}</ref> (born August 10, 1945), also known as Dan Peña, is an American businessman and business [[Coaching|coach]]. He developed QLA (Quantum Leap Advantage) methodology which is based on his years of experience buying and selling businesses. He currently resides at [[Guthrie Castle]], [[Scotland]], United Kingdom where he hosts his exclusive seminars.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/rescued-castle-to-open-its-doors-1-658400|title=Rescued castle to open its doors|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}}</ref>
== Early Life == When he turned 5, they left [[Florida]] and moved to east [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]] where he spent most of his youth. He is the son of Manuel Peña, a former Lieutenant Commander, WWII and Korean War veteran, CIA operative and was the lead investigator for the RFK assassination investigation in 1968.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thewealthrecord.com/celebs-bio-wiki-salary-earnings-2019-2020-2021-2022-2023-2024-2025/businessperson/dan-pena-net-worth/|title=Dan Peña Net Worth|date=2018-08-18|work=The Wealth Record|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
Pena graduated from [[Reseda High School]] in 1963. After that, he went to [[California State University, Northridge|CSUN]] to take up math and engineering until he voluntarily enlisted for the [[United States Army|US Army]] and attended [[Officer Candidate School (United States Army)|OCS (Officer Candidate School)]] at [[Fort Benning South, Georgia|Fort Benning]] on 1966. He held the rank of [[Second lieutenant|Second Lieutenant]] and cooperated with [[NATO]] in the late 1960s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/16202513/Dan-Pena-Speaking-at-CSUN|title=Dan Pena - Speaking at CSUN {{!}} Economies {{!}} Energy And Resource|website=Scribd|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> After graduating from military school, he went back to college and received a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration from [[California State University, Northridge|California State University, Northridge (CSUN)]] in 1971.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/california-state-university-northridge|title=California State University, Northridge|website=Times Higher Education (THE)|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hamlinscientific.com/leadership/|title=Leadership {{!}} Hamlin Scientific|website=hamlinscientific.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Winnerminds|title=English: News article from the Houston Chronicles dated July 12, 1991 where Daniel S Pena, chairman of GWRI made a commencement speech for graduates of California State University.|date=2018-05-31|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Houston_Chronicles_Article_about_GWRI_Chairman_conducting_a_commencement_speech_at_California_State_University.jpg|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref>
== Career == He was the founder, former Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Great Western Resources Inc.(GWRI), a Houston-based natural resources company public on the [[London Stock Exchange]] (LSE) that explores and produces coal. GWRI has operations in US, the [[Gulf of Mexico]], the [[United Kingdom]], and [[South America]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.martawiley.com/martas-mentors.html|title=Marta's Mentors|website=Marta G. Wiley Studios|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://speakerhub.com/speaker/dan-pena|title=Dan Pena {{!}} SpeakerHub|website=SpeakerHub|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Winnerminds|title=English: Proof and photos of the establishment of the company: Great Western Resources Inc. (GWRI) headed by it's chairman and founder Daniel S. Pena Sr.|date=2018-05-31|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Establishment_of_Great_Western_Resource_Inc._(GWRI).jpg|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> In January 1992, Peña was ousted from the company and he then decided to bring the issues to court. He subsequently won and GWRI was asked to pay an undisclosed amount to the former chairman and founder.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Loomis|first=Roger Sherman|date=June 1928|title=Gawain, Gwri, and Cuchulinn|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/457630|journal=PMLA|volume=43|issue=2|pages=384|doi=10.2307/457630|issn=0030-8129}}</ref>
He is also the founder and chairman of [http://www.theguthriegroup.com/ The Guthrie Group], an investment consortium, incorporated on the Channel Islands in 2002. He also founded a company called iZone-iHUB, which ran a hackathon with the stated purposes of allowing start-ups the ability to develop their ideas and pitch products for potential investment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.devcon.ph/event/izone-ihub-24-hour-hackathon/|title=iZone-iHUB 24 Hour Hackathon - DEVCON Philippines - Developers Connect|website=www.devcon.ph|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://geekyfaust.info/news/izone-ihub-the-first-open-tech-site-in-the-philippines/|title=iZone-iHUB the first open tech site in the Philippines|date=2012-11-15|work=GeekyFaust|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wiztechie.com/izone-ihub-pinoy-techies-online-community/|title=iZone-iHUB: Pinoy Techies Online Community|date=2012-11-26|work=WizTechie|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://izone-ihub.blogspot.com/|title=iZone-iHUB|website=izone-ihub.blogspot.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref>
Before he founded GWRI, he was the Chairman of JPK Industries, Inc., a company which focused in the petroleum industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.danlok.com/daniel-s-pena/audios/7-secrets-super-success-audio/|title=7 Secrets for Super Success Audio - Dan Lok - Serial Entrepreneur - Millionaire Mentor|website=www.danlok.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> He was also with the investment banking firm of Bear Stearns and Co. where he advised clients internationally, not just in the USA. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.celebsnetworthtoday.com/bio-wiki-2018-2019-2020-2021/businessperson/dan-pena-net-worth-4739/|title=Dan Pena Net Worth 2018|date=2018-10-11|work=Celebs Net Worth Today|access-date=2018-11-19|language=en-US}}</ref> And he served as President and CEO of Kennedy Industries Inc., a company with interests in real estate, the entertainment/movie industry, insurance and also financial services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.shouldersoftitans.com/interview-with-dan-pena/|title=Ep. 001 - How Ordinary People Can Build Extraordinary Wealth With Quantum Leap Advantage Methodology - Shoulders of Titans|work=Shoulders of Titans|access-date=2018-11-19|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Awards and Recognitions == List of notable rewards and recognition he received throughout the years:
* He was featured on [[Sports Illustrated|Sport Illustrated]] January 1977 issue under "Faces in the Crowd" were he received a trophy in behalf of the editors.<ref>{{Citation|title=Alonzo, Alonzo|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/j.ctv8j4n7.15|work=The Roger Kahn Reader|pages=52–54|publisher=UNP - Nebraska|isbn=9781496207180|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref>
* Appointed by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] as a "Serving Brother" to the Most Venerable [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Order of the Hospital of St John of Jerusalem]], also known as "The Order of St John".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/notice/2871020|title=Order of St John|website=www.thegazette.co.uk|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> * Appointed to the US Presidential Round table Senatorial Commission (1991)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=August 1991|title=White House sweepstakes|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00358536008452236|journal=The Round Table|volume=50|issue=198|pages=156–161|doi=10.1080/00358536008452236|issn=0035-8533|via=}}</ref> *He was commissioned as a [[Kentucky Colonel]] and Commonwealth of Kentucky Admiral on February 7, 1987 by former governor [[Martha Layne Collins|Martha Collins]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Winnerminds|title=English: Daniel S. Peña Sr. was awarded this certificate as proof that he was commissioned as a Kentucky Colonel by Governor Martha Layne Collins.|date=1987-02-07|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Commissioning_Certificate_awarded_to_Daniel_S._Pe%C3%B1a_Sr.png|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Winnerminds|title=English: Daniel S. Peña Sr. was awarded this certificate as proof that he was commissioned as a Admiral by Commonwealth of Kentucy.|date=1987-02-07|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Daniel_S._Pe%C3%B1a_Sr._commissioned_as_an_Admiral_by_the_Commonwealth_of_Kentucky.png|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> * Awarded by The [[Marquis Who's Who]] Publications Board as a subject of biographical record in "Who's Who of Emerging Leaders in America (Second Edition) 1989/1990". Such an award is given only to a limited number of individuals who have demonstrated outstanding achievement in their own fields of endeavor and who have, thereby, contributed significantly to the betterment of contemporary society.<ref>{{Citation|last=Winnerminds|title=English: A document providing validation on Daniel S. Pena being a "Who's Who of Emerging Leaders in America Second Edition" from 1989 to 1990.|date=2018-05-31|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Who%27s_Who_Publication_Board_Certificate.jpg|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> * He has been featured in many US publications such as the [[Los Angeles Times]] (an article entitled “Latino Wealthy - A New Breed” written by [[Al Martinez]] which won the [[Pulitzer Prize]])<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/24191341/Dan-Pena-La-Times|title=Dan Pena La Times|website=Scribd|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> * He was also featured on dozens of publications such as [[Financial Times|The Financial Times]], Success Now Magazine, Hispanic Business, The National Law Journal, Movers & Shakers, Press and Journal, The Fresno Bee, Investor’s Business Daily, The Times, Dimokratia (Greek Newspaper), along with the Dutch publications OBJEKT, Bouwteam and Limburg Bagblad. He was also featured on US, UK, Chinese, Philippine and German television.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dimokratianews.gr/content/90237/pos-na-gineis-disekatommyrioyhos|title=Πώς να γίνεις δισεκατομμυριούχος|date=2018-09-11|website=δημοκρατία|language=el|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Dan Pena|title=Dan Pena's Interview with Susan Barlin on Philippine National TV|date=2013-02-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e_CRO4fppEo|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Dan Pena|title=iZone-iHUB Founder Dan Pena at Ka Iking Live|date=2012-11-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5tFPQ4WjE4w|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref>
== Publications == Here are some of of the books he published throughout his career in business:
* Your First Hundred Million - First Edition (June 1, 1999) {{ISBN|9781871379303}} * Your First Hundred Million - Second Edition (April 18, 2016) {{ISBN|9789719421825}}
== Philanthropy == He participates in various charitable activities, such as: “Faith Foundation” a Primary school in Rwanda<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/dan-pe%C3%B1a-supports-faith-foundation-rwanda-africa-dan-pe%C3%B1a|title=Dan Peña Supports the Faith Foundation in Rwanda, Africa|website=www.linkedin.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref>, Holy Family Mission in Sri Lanka, Student Athlete High School Scholarships in name of Dan's father, Manuel S. Peña, at Lincoln High School in East LA (USA), The Wounded Warriors in the USA<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lincolnheights.dollarsforscholars.org/index.php?section=chapterWebsite&action=about&fwID=2017&cmsID=43607&cmsIDck=b6fe57ad6e045e80d6fabcfb365e6a39|title=Dollars For Scholars - Lincoln Heights Dollars for Scholars|website=www.lincolnheights.dollarsforscholars.org|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref> and also provided financial support and donation to his blind friend and mentee Tony Ward, who established the [https://www.fightingblindness.ie/ Fighting Blindness Charity Institution in Ireland].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://give.everydayhero.com/ie/tony-ward-new-york-marathon|title=Help support Tony Ward’s 2015 New York City marathon challenge make a difference|website=give.everydayhero.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}</ref>
== Controversies == In March 2006, an Indian software engineer alleged that Peña, Peña's wife, Sally Hall, and employee Bill William Smith{{cn|date=May 2018}}, had deceived him and stolen credit card details from illegal proxy websites that they operated. Smith was arrested in [[Bangalore]] and all thre were charged under the Information Technology Act of 2000.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-three-foreigners-swindle-thousands-from-b-lore-1094863 |title=Three foreigners swindle thousands from B'lore |date=May 7, 2007}}</ref>
In August 2009 the cyber crime police in [[India]] told the ''I ACMM'' court that it was a "mistake of facts" and the court officially acquitted him of all charges. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Firm-chairman-director-cleared-of-charges/articleshow/4872276.cms|title=Firm chairman, director cleared of charges - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-04-21}}</ref>{{Additional citation needed|date=May 2018|reason= Single source}}
Last 2017, a wedding planner named Craig Williamson at Guthrie Castle stole £130,000 from couples who booked the wedding venue to fund his gambling habit and then fled to [[Ibiza]]. He was then arrested and sentenced to jail for two and a half years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/13/wedding-planner-scottish-castle-jailed-two-and-a-half-years/|title=Wedding planner at Scottish castle jailed for two-and-a-half years for fraud|last=Johnson|first=Simon|date=2017-09-13|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecourier.co.uk/fp/news/local/angus-mearns/409071/alleged-guthrie-castle-fraud-may-have-been-going-on-since-2015/|title=Alleged Guthrie Castle fraud may have been going on since 2015 - The Courier|work=The Courier|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}}</ref> The castle owner, was later interviewed by [[BBC News (TV channel)|BBC News]] and he said that he honored and refunded all the couples affected by this unfortunate incident.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-41253642|title=Castle owner forgives wedding fraudster|date=2017-09-14|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pena, Daniel S. Sr.}} [[Category:American financiers]] [[Category:American investors]] [[Category:California State University, Northridge alumni]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American motivational speakers]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Life coaches]] [[Category:Personal development]] [[Category:21st-century American businesspeople]]

{{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{refimprove|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Department of Skills Development |type = Department |nativename = Jabatan Pembangunan Kemahiran
(DSD / JSK) |logo = [[File:Department of Skills Development.jpg|300px]] |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Malaysia]] |headquarters = |coordinates = |motto = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = [[M. Kulasegaran]] |minister1_pfo = [[Minister of Human Resources (Malaysia)|Minister of Human Resources]] |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |agency_type = |parent_department = [[Ministry of Human Resources (Malaysia)|Ministry of Human Resources]] |keydocument1 = |website = {{URL|http://www.dsd.gov.my/}} }} The '''Department of Skills Development''' ({{lang-ms|Jabatan Pembangunan Kemahiran}}, abbreviated '''DSD''' or '''JPK''') is an agency under the [[Ministry of Human Resources (Malaysia)|Ministry of Human Resources]] for co-ordination and control of training skills for Malaysian citizens. It researches and develops standards to evaluate job expertise and competency. ==Organisation== The agency is led by a Director General, assisted by a Deputy Director General and a Legal Adviser. Department of Skill Development's functions are further delegated to 14 agencies. Each agency is led by a director. ==Malaysian Skill Certificate== Defining the contents of Sijil Kemahiran Malaysia (Malaysian Skill Certificates) is the major function of Department of Skill Development. There are currently five different levels of certification. Skill Certificates are obtained through Accredited Training Institutions and Industry-Oriented Training. Apprenticeship training courses in the National Dual Training System are carried out in approved institutes. Separately, Pengiktirafan Pencapaian Terdahulu (PPT) (Recognition of Prior Achievement) allow trainees or trainers to convert their experience (either in work or training) into Sijil Kemahiran Malaysia. Malaysians can be awarded SKM without formal courses. They submit proof of such experience and the evidence is reviewed by the relevant officers and confirmed by the Pegawai Pengesahan Luaran, who is usually from the Department of Skill Development. ==Accredited Centres== Malaysian Skills Certificates are awarded to trainees who complete the course at the centres accredited by the agency. Accredited centres are divided into: 1) Public Approved Centres 2) Private Approved Centres 30 Industrial Approved Centres 4) Association Approved Centres 5) National Dual Training (NDT) Approved Centres ==National Occupational Skills Standard== National Occupational Skills Standard (NOSS) specifies level of competency required by a worker to perform a specific job at different levels. A syllabus describes each skill and level. ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.dsd.gov.my/}} {{Federal Government of Malaysia}} [[Category:Malaysian federal ministries, departments and agencies]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Malaysia]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 2006]] [[Category:Ministry of Human Resources (Malaysia)]] [[Category:Training organizations]]

The '''Distance Learning and Telemedicine Grant and Loan Program''' ('''DLT''') is a program authorized by the 1990 farm bill (P.L. 101-624) to provide grants to rural schools and health care providers to help them invest in telecommunications facilities and equipment to bring educational and medical resources to rural areas where the services otherwise might be unavailable. The [[1996 farm bill]] (P.L. 104-127) reauthorized and streamlined the program.
The program was also reauthorized in the [[2002 farm bill]] (P.L. 107-171, Sec. 6203).
DLT is administered by the [[Rural Utilities Service]].
== References ==
*{{CRS|article = Report for Congress: Agriculture: A Glossary of Terms, Programs, and Laws, 2005 Edition|url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110810044532/http://ncseonline.org/nle/crsreports/05jun/97-905.pdf|author= Jasper Womach}}
==External links== * [http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/UTP_DLT.html Distance Learning and Telemedicine Grant and Loan Program] official website
[[Category:United States Department of Agriculture programs]] [[Category:Telehealth]] [[Category:Health informatics]] [[Category:Health education]] [[Category:Distance education institutions based in the United States]]

{{Orphan|date=April 2016}}
'''DocNet''' is a [[consortium]] of [[university]] [[business school]]s granting [[Doctoral|doctoral degrees]] in [[business administration]] and [[economics]]. The organization states its mission as: :"...To promote doctoral education in business throughout the world. The organization educates potential students about careers in academia and engages in a variety of recruiting strategies aimed at increasing the pool of qualified applicants for doctoral-granting institutions. DocNet members share information about best practices, curriculum and admissions issues, student support, and placement. DocNet also lobbies for doctoral programs within its members' respective colleges and universities and at the national level through [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business|AACSB]] International, the [[Graduate Management Admission Council]], and the media." [http://www.businessdoctoralprograms.org/id2.html]

{{One source|date=April 2016}} '''ETS Europe''' is the [[Europe]]an arm of [[Educational Testing Service]], an American company, involved in scholastic assessment in Europe.
==History== It is headquartered in [[Utrecht]] in the [[Netherlands]]. ETS employs about 2,700 individuals, including 240 with [[doctorate]]s and an additional 350 others with "higher degrees." Work that ETS does that is not associated with its nonprofit educational research mission is conducted by for-profit subsidiaries, such as [[Prometric]], which administers test by computer for licensing and certification in the professional world, and [[ETS Global BV]], which contains much of the international operations of the company.
About 25% of the work carried out by ETS is contracted by the private, [[not-for-profit]] firm, the [[College Board]]. The most popular of the College Board's tests is the [[SAT]], taken by more than 3 million students annually. ETS also develops and administers The College Board's [[Advanced Placement]] program, which is widely used in US high schools for advanced course credit.
==England and Wales Controversy== In England and [[Wales]] ETS Europe were contracted to operate the [[National Curriculum (England, Wales and Northern Ireland)|National Curriculum]] assessments on behalf of the government. ETS took over this role from [[Edexcel]] in 2008. The first year of their operation was struck by a number of problems, including the late arrival of scripts to examiners, a database of student entries being unavailable, and countrywide reports of problems with the marking of the papers. The opposition Conservative party has criticised the awarding of the contracts to ETS, and produced a dossier listing previous problems with ETS' service. Their contract with the [[Qualifications and Curriculum Development Agency|QCA]] was terminated in August 2008: ETS is to pay back £19.5m and cancel invoices worth £4.6m. The UK government asked Lord Sutherland to conduct an inquiry into the failure of the 2008 tests. The report included in its main findings: *Primary responsibility for this summer's delivery failure rests with ETS Global BV, which won the public contract to deliver the tests *ETS's capacity to deliver the contract proved to be insufficient. A lack of comprehensive planning and testing by ETS of its systems and processes was a key factor in the delivery failure.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/229092/0062.pdf |title=The Sutherland Inquiry |publisher=[[The Stationery Office]] |date=16 December 2008 |accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Educational assessment and evaluation]]
