{{unreferenced|date=March 2010}} {{Infobox Organization |name =The Fund for Constitutional Government |leader_title =President |leader_name =[[Anne B. Zill|Anne Zill]] |headquarters =[[Washington, D.C.]] |formation =1974 |website =[http://www.fcgonline.org/index.html www.fcgonline.org/index.html] }}
The '''Fund for Constitutional Government''' ('''FCG''') is a publicly supported, charitable, nonprofit corporation that supports or fiscally sponsors organizations and journalists dedicated the exposure and correction of corruption and the violation of constitutional principles in the U.S. federal government as well as other major national organizations. Located on Capitol Hill, FCG works to bring to light instances of corruption which have a large public impact, have a precedent-setting value, and which, if rectified, will aid in preserving an open and accountable government.
==Major Projects== FCG supports a number of influential non-governmental organizations that focus on government oversight and accountability including:
*[[Project on Government Oversight]] *[[Electronic Privacy Information Center]] *[[Government Accountability Project]] *Open the Government *The Investigative Journalism Project
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fund For Constitutional Government}} [[Category:Whistleblower support organizations]] [[Category:Civil rights organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Transparency (behavior)]]

{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=December 2016}} {{notability|Companies|date=December 2016}} {{unreliable sources|date=December 2016}} }} '''The Intern Group''' is a provider of international [[internship]] programs in [[Tokyo]], [[Toronto]], [[Shanghai]], [[San Francisco]], [[Dublin]], [[Chicago]], [[Santiago, Chile]], [[London]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Melbourne, Australia]], [[Medellin, Colombia]], [[Madrid]], [[New York City]], and [[Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theinterngroup.com/|title=International Internship Program With The Intern Group|website=International Internships}}</ref>
== History == The company was founded and keeps its head office in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wck2.companieshouse.gov.uk//compdetails|title=Failure Page|website=wck2.companieshouse.gov.uk}}</ref> It has offices in New York, Melbourne, Madrid, Hong Kong, Colombia and also [[Santiago]], [[Chile]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vanessa|first1=Van Edwards|title=Start-Up Chile: Growing Pains of the Chilecon Valley|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/vanessa-van-edwards/start-up-chile_b_3225480.html|website=Huffington Post}}</ref>
== Costs == Depending on the location of the internship different fees apply to the participating student.
In 2018 the standard fees for a 6-week programme in some major cities were as following:
* London: $6,099 * Barcelona: $5,236 * Shanghai: $4,630
For summer internships higher fees apply.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theinterngroup.com/program-fees/#parentHorizontalTab1|title=Program Fees & Start Dates - International Internships|work=International Internships|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Partnerships ==
The Intern Group has a partnerships with universities from all over the world. A few partnerships include University of Pennsylvania, Boston University, Northeastern, Kings College London, the [https://career.ust.hk/web/page.php?sid=45 Hong Kong University of Science and Technology],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://career.ust.hk/web/page.php?sid=45|title=Career Center - The HKUST|website=career.ust.hk}}</ref> [https://www.newcastle.edu.au/research-and-innovation/graduate-research/current-students/support-and-resources/training-and-development University of Newcastle],<ref>{{cite web|title=Internships and Placements|url=http://www.newcastle.edu.au/international/study-with-us/study-abroad-and-exchange/study-overseas/where-can-i-go/internships-and-placements|website=Newcastle University|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref> the [[University of New South Wales]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Education Programs|url=http://blogs.unsw.edu.au/globaled/blog/2014/10/the-intern-group-international-internship-programs-in-hong-kong-madrid-london-and-colombia/|website=University of New South Wales|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref> and [http://www.latrobe.edu.au/students/exchange/short-programs La Trobe University]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latrobe.edu.au/students/exchange/short-programs|title=Overseas short programs|first=La Trobe|last=University|website=www.latrobe.edu.au}}</ref> in Australia. [http://www.lse.ac.uk/study/generalCourse/prospectiveStudents/Internships.aspx London School of Economics (LSE),] <ref>{{Cite web|title = Internships - Prospective students - A year at LSE: the General Course - Study - Home|url = http://www.lse.ac.uk/study/generalCourse/prospectiveStudents/Internships.aspx|website = www.lse.ac.uk|access-date = 2016-02-24|first = LSE Corporate Web|last = Editor}}</ref> [http://ucscinternational.unicatt.it/ucsc-international-programmi-internship-londra-hong-kong-madrid-bogota-melbourne Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore] (UCSC), <ref>http://ucscinternational.unicatt.it/ucsc-international-programmi-internship-londra-hong-kong-madrid-bogota-melbourne</ref> [https://www.nshss.org/member-benefits/scholarships/ The National Society of High School Scholars] (NSHSS),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nshss.org/member-benefits/scholarships/|title=College & High School Scholarships - NSHSS Scholarship Organization - National Society of High School Scholars|first=National Society of High School|last=Scholars|website=www.nshss.org}}</ref> [http://www.um.edu.ar/es/internacional/convocatorias.html Universidad de Mendoza]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.um.edu.ar/es/internacional/convocatorias.html|title=Convocatorias|first=Paula Vazquez|last=Viera|website=www.um.edu.ar}}</ref> [http://www.essex.ac.uk/essexabroad/work-research/default.aspx University of Essex]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.essex.ac.uk/essexabroad/work-research/default.aspx|title=Essex Abroad|last=|first=|date=|website=University of Essex|publisher=|access-date=22 June 2016}}</ref> and National University of Singapore (NUS), also have partnerships with The Intern Group, providing students with academic credit for their internships.<ref>{{cite web|title=International Internships|url=http://www.nus.edu.sg/iro/opps/intern/ig/index.html|website=National University of Singapore|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref>.
==External links== [https://www.theinterngroup.com/contact-us/ Company website]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox school |name = Waldorf School of San Diego |image = Waldorf logo.jpg |location = 4135 54th Place |city = San Diego |state = California |zipcode = 92105 |country = United States |established = 1981 |type = [[Private school|Private]], [[Waldorf school]] |enrollment = 284 |homepage = {{url|waldorfsandiego.org}} }} '''Waldorf School of San Diego''' ('''WSSD''') is an independent [[Waldorf school]] located in the [[Oak Park, San Diego, California|Oak Park neighborhood]] of [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], [[California]], United States. It offers preschool/kindergarten through 12th grade, and had an enrollment of 284 in 2011.<ref name=review>[http://www.privateschoolreview.com/school_ov/school_id/4606 Private School Review: The Waldorf School of San Diego]. Accessed 2011-09-23.</ref> Founded in 1981, it is one of approximately more than 250 independent [[North America]]n and 1,000 worldwide Waldorf schools. The school is an accredited member school of the Association of Waldorf Schools of North America].<ref>[http://awsna.org Association of Waldorf Schools of North America]</ref><ref>[http://www.members.awsna.org/Public/SchoolListPage.aspx AWSNA Member School List]. Accessed 2011-12-20.</ref>
In September 2008, the school inaugurated its high school program with Grade 9.<ref>[http://www.visionmagazine.com/archives/0712/living_arts_waldorf.html High School on the Horizon: Waldorf to Break Ground Soon], ''Vision Magazine'', December 2007. Accessed 2008-09-23.</ref>
The school has received financial support and guidance from the [[RSF Social Finance|Rudolf Steiner Foundation]].<ref>[http://www.rsfsocialfinance.org/projects/new-borrowers-in-2007/ RSF Social Finance: New Borrowers in 2007]. Accessed 2008-09-23.</ref>
The Waldorf School of San Diego also serves as a campus for the Waldorf [[Teacher education|teacher training]] program of the Waldorf Institute of Southern California.<ref>[http://www.waldorfteaching.org/ Waldorf Institute of Southern California]</ref><ref>[http://www.waldorfteaching.org/waldorf_institute_contact_info.html#campus_locations Campus Locations], Waldorf Institute of Southern California. Accessed 2011-12-20.</ref>
==Curriculum== The curriculum of the Waldorf School of San Diego is based on the [[Waldorf education|educational philosophy]] developed by [[Rudolf Steiner]]. Each grade provides educational activities that are designed to respond to the physical, emotional, intellectual and spiritual needs at that stage of the children's development. The [[visual arts]], [[music]] and other [[performing arts]], and [[Handicraft|handcrafts]] are emphasized, as well as traditional subjects including reading, English, history, mathematics, science, and geography.
The hallmark of a Waldorf education is the schooling of the head, heart and hands. The school's goal is not only to develop each child's intellect but to ensure that they will engage themselves in the world with an open heart. Working with the hands is one of the ways to develop the neurological passageways that establish the foundation of thinking. Conscious development and training of the hands using diverse mediums such as copper work, stained glass, beeswax, woodwork, blacksmithing, and felting, leads to enhanced cognition and understanding for the students. Another hallmark is the integration of an artistic component into every academic subject, even history, math and science. This keeps the students interested and engaged in the most difficult topics exciting and fun.
The early childhood program is play-based so that each child can develop vital social and emotional skills, as well as artistic and imaginative skills (the foundation for memory and retention). The focus is also on building a strong, healthy physical body through plenty of outdoor play, bio-dynamic gardening, daily movement in circle time with songs, verses and games, and organic food served daily. The fine and gross motor skills are refined so that a foundation is laid for the academic work that begins in grade 1.
In grades 1-8, there is no testing or grading, so the work done by each student comes from a genuine love of learning. The Main Lesson teacher who leads most of the academic work consistently assesses each student's progress throughout the year, and parents receive a substantial year-end report. There is also a short written report from each of the 7-8 Special Subjects teachers.
The school's [[gardening]] program has included instruction in [[Biodynamic agriculture|biodynamic]] [[composting]]<ref>Linda C. Puig, [http://www.sdearthtimes.com/et0498/et0498s10.html Kids and composting were made for each other], ''San Diego Earth Times'', April 1998. Accessed 2008-09-23.</ref> and a project to plant [[fruit tree]]s on the campus.<ref>[http://www.medinacreative.com/clients/fruittree/accomplishments.htm Planting Fruit Trees for a Healthier Planet], The Fruit Tree Planting Foundation, 2005. Accessed 2008-09-23.</ref>
Following the strong foundation of early childhood and the elementary grades, the students are well prepared for the rigorous academic work brought in high school, where they receive a broad and rich education. In high school, the students are developmentally ready for testing and grading, which is documented in mid-year and year-end report cards - all closely monitored by the student in conjunction with each subject teacher (up to 14 different teachers, each an expert in their field of study). The social and community service that is an integral part of the high school journey helps the teenager navigate adolescence with a warm heart and a sense of purpose. The end result is an enlivening education which puts a high value on Waldorf students at colleges and universities across the country and abroad.
Curriculum related field trips begin in grade 1 and continue through to grade 12. There is a particular focus on sustainable outdoor adventure, along with social and community service in the two week trips at the end of grade 8 and grade 11.
The school offers a wide variety of sports, including [[Track and field athletics|track and field]], [[golf]], [[Association football|soccer]], [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[tennis]], [[water polo]], and [[dance]].<ref name=review/> Beginning in the 6th grade, students may join the girls' or boys' basketball team, or the co-ed soccer team, all of which compete in local leagues.
==See also== *[[Waldorf education]] *[[Curriculum of the Waldorf schools]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Additional articles== * [http://www.visionmagazine.com/archives/0712/living_arts_waldorf.html High School on the Horizon: Waldorf to Break Ground Soon], ''Vision Magazine'', December 2007. Accessed 2008-09-23. * [http://www.sandiegomagazine.com/media/San-Diego-Magazine/January-2011/Private-School-Guide/] ''San Diego Magazine'', January 2011. Accessed 2011-12-20.
==External links== * [http://waldorfsandiego.org/ Official website] * [http://www.whywaldorfworks.org/ Why Waldorf works]

revision.text:
'''William Hobart Dickey''' (December 15, 1928 – May 3, 1994) was an [[United States|American]] [[poet]] and professor of English and creative writing at [[San Francisco State University]]. He authored 15 books of poetry over a career that lasted three and a half decades.
==Early life and education==
Dickey was born in 1928 in [[Bellingham, Washington]] and was raised in [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] and [[Oregon]]. He attended [[Reed College]], graduating in 1951. At Reed he wrote a novel for his bachelor's thesis and was elected to the [[Phi Beta Kappa Society]].<ref name=DLB>{{cite book |title=[[Dictionary of Literary Biography]] |volume=5 |editor-first=Donald J. |editor-last=Greiner |chapter=William Dickey |last=Goldstein |first=Thomas |year=1980 |publisher=Gale |pages=191–195}}</ref>
He was awarded a [[Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation|Woodrow Wilson Fellowship]] and went on to study at [[Harvard University]] ([[Master of Arts|M.A.]], 1955) and the [[University of Iowa]] ([[Master of Fine Arts|M.F.A.]], 1956). As a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright scholar]] he studied at [[Jesus College, Oxford|Jesus College]] at the [[University of Oxford]] from 1959 to 1960.<ref name=DLB/>
Dickey was a student of [[John Berryman]] at the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]]. He later recalled:
{{quote|First to have been at [[Reed College]] as an undergraduate with [[Gary Snyder]], [[Philip Whalen]] and [[Lew Welch]], second to have been in John Berryman's extraordinary and intense poetry workshop with W. D. Snodgrass, [[Donald Justice]], [[Philip Levine (poet)|Philip Levine]], [[Paul Petrie]], [[Robert Dana]], [[Constance Urdang]], [[Jane Cooper]], [[Donald Finkel]], [[Henri Coulette]]—the list continues beyond the capacity of my memory, but it was a course I approached with rapture and fear, owing in part to Berryman's sometimes jagged abruptness, as when, having warned me beforehand that he was going to exhibit the profound mortality of one of my works, he held it out at arm's length in the class, looked at it with loathing, and said, "Now, what are we to say about this ridiculous poem?"<ref>{{cite book |title=Seems Like Old Times |editor-first=Ed |editor-last=Dinger |year=1986 |publisher=University of Iowa}}</ref>}}
==Literary and academic career==
Dickey's first collection of poetry, ''Of the Festivity'', was selected by [[W.H. Auden]] as the winner of the [[Yale Series of Younger Poets Competition]] in 1959. In the foreword to the book, Auden wrote:
{{quote|It is possible to show evidence of great intelligence and sensibility but to be lacking in the first power essential to poetry, the power to speak, Mr. Dickey's lines have both.<ref name=Times>{{cite news |title=William Dickey, Poet and Teacher, Is Dead at 65 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=1994-05-11 |accessdate=2009-06-21 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/11/obituaries/william-dickey-poet-and-teacher-is-dead-at-65.html}}</ref>}}
Among Dickey's subsequent collections of poetry, ''More Under Saturn'' won a silver medal from the [[Commonwealth Club of California]] in 1972, and ''The Rainbow Grocery'' received the Juniper Prize from the [[University of Massachusetts Press]] in 1978.<ref name=PF>{{cite web |title=William H. Dickey (1928 - 1994) |url=http://www.poetryfoundation.org/archive/poet.html?id=1774 |publisher=[[Poetry Foundation]] |accessdate=2009-06-21}}</ref>
Dickey was an instructor in English at [[Cornell University]] from 1956 to 1959, and an assistant professor of English at [[Denison University]] from 1960 to 1962. In 1962 he joined the faculty of [[San Francisco State University]] as a professor of English and creative writing, teaching there until his retirement in 1991.<ref name=PF/>
==Personal life==
Dickey lived in [[San Francisco]] with his companion Leonard Sanazaro, a poet who taught English and creative writing at the [[City College of San Francisco]].<ref name=Times/>
Dickey died in 1994 at [[Kaiser Permanente|Kaiser Hospital]] in San Francisco. The cause was complications from [[HIV]]-related surgeries.<ref name=Times/><ref name=BAP97>{{cite book |title=The Best American Poetry 1997 |editor1-first=David |editor1-last=Lehman |editor1-link=David Lehman |editor2-first=James |editor2-last=Tate |editor2-link=James Tate (writer) |year=1997 |publisher=Scribner |pages=209–210 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tl9KNKvGjfkC&pg=PA209}}</ref> Shortly before his death, Dickey finished a poem, "The Death of [[John Berryman]]," about the suicide of his former teacher. It was published posthumously in ''[[Poetry (magazine)|Poetry]]'' (January 1996) and ''[[The Best American Poetry 1997]]''.<ref name=BAP97/>
In 1996 a collection of Dickey's poems and books was deposited at the Gay and Lesbian Center at the [[San Francisco Public Library]].<ref>{{cite web |title=William Dickey, Poems 1981-1995 |url=http://sfpl.org/librarylocations/main/glc/pdf/William_Dickey.pdf |publisher= [[San Francisco Public Library]] |accessdate=2009-06-21}}</ref>
==Published work==
Dickey's published works of poetry include:
* ''Of the Festivity'' (Yale University Press, 1959) * ''Interpreter's House'' (Ohio State University Press, 1963) * ''Rivers of the Pacific Northwest'' (Twowindows Press, 1969) * ''More Under Saturn'' (Wesleyan University Press, 1971) * ''Sheena'' (Funge Art Centre, Gorey, Ireland, 1975) * ''The Rainbow Grocery'' ([[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1978) * ''The Sacrifice Consenting'' (Pterodactyl Press, 1981) * ''Six Philosophical Songs'' (Pterodactyl Press, 1983) * ''Joy'' (Pterodactyl Press, 1983) * ''Brief Lives'' (Heyeck Press, 1985) * ''The King of the Golden River'' (Pterodactyl Press, 1985) * ''In the Dreaming'' (University of Arkansas Press, 1994) * ''The Education of Desire'' (University Press of New England, 1996)
His poems have also appeared in many anthologies, including:
* ''[[The Best American Poetry 1996]]'' ("The Arrival of the Titanic") * ''[[The Best American Poetry 1997]]'' ("The Death of John Berryman")
Dickey also experimented with Hypercard poetry, which is available at the Maryland Institute of Technology in the Humanities (Mechanisms: new media and the forensic imagination By Matthew G. Kirschenbaum)
